messages.text: Hello everyone, not sure where to post this. Being a newb at programming and Linux, I seem to have borked my system somehow. I was trying to follow along Tom Kwong's awesome video on TextAnalysis.jl, when I started experiencing some weird problems loading OhMyREPL and Pluto. Both packages seem to precompile forever, and then I get `StackOverflowError`s. My question is whether to report these as issues/bugs, and if so where? I downloaded `rr` and created a trace of my startup (since I had OhMyREPL in my `startup.jl` file). Given that I am getting the same error for two different packages, I don't think this needs to be reported under either but perhaps under the Julia project itself.

messages.text: How can I write a simple RPC in Julia? I want to take some simple I/O transport (pipes / sockets / websockets / etc.), some serialization protocol (JSON / MsgPack), and a multiplexer to route messages to corresponding functions. Is HTTP-protocol and routers from HTTP.jl the only option? What if I don't want to use HTTP - should I write it myself, or is there some non-HTTP standards or packages?

messages.text:
Hi guys, first Merry Christmas for everyone who celebrate this date. Second, I have quite an intricate problem here. I'm trying to use a C library in my Julia code. I have a structure (say S) in the Julia side where I have an array of pointers (say S.array). In the Julia side I initalize S.array[i] to be C_NULL for every i. The C code allocates memory for the entries in the S.array, so after calling the C code, S.array[0], for example, is populated. The problem is that I'm getting an error when trying to do unsafe_load(S.array[1]) (changed from 0 to 1 because of Julia's index system). Debugging the code I discovered the following:
• The address of S.array is the same, both on Julia and C side.
• The address of S.array[0] in C is different than S.array[1] in Julia.
I already tried doing unsafe_wrap on S.array, but same error happens. I'm not sure how to proceed here. Any help is greatly appreciated. Thanks!

elements.text: Hi guys, first Merry Christmas for everyone who celebrate this date. Second, I have quite an intricate problem here. I'm trying to use a C library in my Julia code. I have a structure (say S) in the Julia side where I have an array of pointers (say S.array). In the Julia side I initalize S.array[i] to be C_NULL for every i. The C code allocates memory for the entries in the S.array, so after calling the C code, S.array[0], for example, is populated. The problem is that I'm getting an error when trying to do unsafe_load(S.array[1]) (changed from 0 to 1 because of Julia's index system). Debugging the code I discovered the following:
The address of S.array is the same, both on Julia and C side.
The address of S.array[0] in C is different than S.array[1] in Julia.
I already tried doing unsafe_wrap on S.array, but same error happens. I'm not sure how to proceed here. Any help is greatly appreciated. Thanks!

messages.text: Given na, nb, how can I quickly convert a Cartesian index (ia, ib) to a linear index, without construct the whole matrix for linearindex (i.e. `LinearIndices((1:na, 1:nb))`?

elements.text: Given na, nb, how can I quickly convert a Cartesian index (ia, ib) to a linear index, without construct the whole matrix for linearindex (i.e.
LinearIndices((1:na, 1:nb))

messages.text:
```julia> na = nb = 10; LinearIndices((1:na, 1:nb)) |> Base.summarysize
32

julia> na = nb = 10000; LinearIndices((1:na, 1:nb)) |> Base.summarysize
32```
it’s not a whole matrix

elements.text:
julia> na = nb = 10; LinearIndices((1:na, 1:nb)) |> Base.summarysize
32

julia> na = nb = 10000; LinearIndices((1:na, 1:nb)) |> Base.summarysize
32
it’s not a whole matrix
You can see that only 4 integers are stored

messages.text:
I wrote a loop with a `cis` call on complex types (see code pasted below), and I was hoping to get this to vectorize appropriately. However, looking at the `@code_llvm` output, it does not appear to vectorize, so I just wanted to see if anyone could help me out understanding if I should even expect this loop to vectorize, or how I might rewrite it in a way that will. I am not particularly experienced in reading the `@code_llvm` output, so it _is_ possible that the code does vectorize, although looking at runtimes for varying array sizes -- as done in the pasted code -- would indicate that it is not. Thanks for any help!

```function Heisenberg!(ρₕ, ρ, ω, τ)
    for i in eachindex(ρ, ρₕ, ω)
        @inbounds ρₕ[i] = ρ[i] * cis(ω[i] * τ)
    end
    return nothing
end

n = 1
dρ = ComplexF32.(rand(n,n))
ρ₀ = ComplexF32.(rand(n,n))
ω = ComplexF32.(rand(n,n))
τ = 1.0f0
@btime Heisenberg!($dρ, $ρ₀, $ω, $τ)
8.399 ns (0 allocations: 0 bytes)

n = 2
dρ = ComplexF32.(rand(n,n))
ρ₀ = ComplexF32.(rand(n,n))
ω = ComplexF32.(rand(n,n))
τ = 1.0f0
@btime Heisenberg!($dρ, $ρ₀, $ω, $τ)
21.542 ns (0 allocations: 0 bytes)

n = 12
dρ = ComplexF32.(rand(n,n))
ρ₀ = ComplexF32.(rand(n,n))
ω = ComplexF32.(rand(n,n))
τ = 1.0f0
@btime Heisenberg!($dρ, $ρ₀, $ω, $τ)
831.313 ns (0 allocations: 0 bytes)```

messages.text:
Hi, I’m just starting out with Julia and ran into a weird issue. I defined a function that can take float values (fp32 or fp64, but strictly no int) as follows
```function elim(A::Array{float},b::Array{float})
    #=
    Function which transforms matrix
    A into upper triangular matrix U
    =#
    n = size(b)[1]
    
    # Pick a pivot row
    for k in 1:n-1
        for i in k+1:n
            if A[i,k] != 0
                lambda = A[i,k]/A[k,k]
                A[i,k+1:n] -= lambda*A[k,k+1:n]
                b[i,:] -= lambda*b[k,:]
            end
        end
    end
    return A, b
end```
Now when I call this function and give inputs as Float32
```A = [[6, -4, 1] [-4, 6, -4] [1, -4, 6]]
b = [[-14, 36, 6] [22, -18, 7]];
A = Float32.(A)
b = Float32.(b);

U, b_t = elim(A,b)
show(stdout, "text/plain", U)
println()
show(stdout, "text/plain", b_t)```
I get an error saying
```MethodError: no method matching elim(::Array{Float32,2}, ::Array{Float32,2})

Stacktrace:
 [1] top-level scope at In[3]:1
 [2] include_string(::Function, ::Module, ::String, ::String) at ./loading.jl:1091```
I get the same error when I input Float64. Is there any way that I can define a function that takes both Float32 and Float64? I don’t want to define two separate functions as it’ll just clutter everything for no reason.

elements.text: Hi, I’m just starting out with Julia and ran into a weird issue. I defined a function that can take float values (fp32 or fp64, but strictly no int) as follows

function elim(A::Array{float},b::Array{float})
    #=
    Function which transforms matrix
    A into upper triangular matrix U
    =#
    n = size(b)[1]
    
    # Pick a pivot row
    for k in 1:n-1
        for i in k+1:n
            if A[i,k] != 0
                lambda = A[i,k]/A[k,k]
                A[i,k+1:n] -= lambda*A[k,k+1:n]
                b[i,:] -= lambda*b[k,:]
            end
        end
    end
    return A, b
end
Now when I call this function and give inputs as Float32

A = [[6, -4, 1] [-4, 6, -4] [1, -4, 6]]
b = [[-14, 36, 6] [22, -18, 7]];
A = Float32.(A)
b = Float32.(b);

U, b_t = elim(A,b)
show(stdout, "text/plain", U)
println()
show(stdout, "text/plain", b_t)
I get an error saying

MethodError: no method matching elim(::Array{Float32,2}, ::Array{Float32,2})

Stacktrace:
 [1] top-level scope at In[3]:1
 [2] include_string(::Function, ::Module, ::String, ::String) at ./loading.jl:1091

I get the same error when I input Float64. Is there any way that I can define a function that takes both Float32 and Float64? I don’t want to define two separate functions as it’ll just clutter everything for no reason.

messages.text:
Just curious how this is done in Matlab. Seems like depending on what variable you assign the result to you get different function calls.
Is this possible in Julia?
```e = eig(A) returns a column vector containing the eigenvalues of square matrix A.
example
[V,D] = eig(A) returns diagonal matrix D of eigenvalues and matrix V whose columns are the corresponding right eigenvectors, so that A*V = V*D.```
<https://www.mathworks.com/help/matlab/ref/nargout.html>

messages.text:
Ok, so I created a macro `@each` that just prints out each line in an iterator:
```macro each(iterator)
    quote
        @info $(sprint(Base.show_unquoted, iterator)) * ":"
        for e in $iterator
            @info "--> $e"
        end
    end
end```
This works well when I run it in the same file:
```x = 1:3
@each x```
results in:
```[ Info: x:
[ Info: --> 1
[ Info: --> 2
[ Info: --> 3```
but  when I do the same in the REPL I get this:
```julia> y = 1:10
1:10

julia> @each y
[ Info: y:
ERROR: UndefVarError: y not defined```
What is happening here?

What is happening here?

I have a weird problem with passing a callback function pointer (returned by `@cfunction`) to a shared library. The function pointer is passed to the library via a field of a structure.  I have added a test function to the shared library that calls the callback function stored in the structure.  I can `ccall` this test function from Julia and the Julia callback function gets called as expected without problems, but when it comes time for the library to call the same callback function it segfaults even though the callback function pointer has the same value as when called from the test function.  Any ideas on what could be going wrong or how to debug this?

messages.text: How would I go about expanding the following code for any number of vectors (possibly using `Iterators` or `@nloops`)?  My code below shows it working for the first three vectors.

files.name: Untitled
files.title: Untitled
files.preview:
function list_span(u̲::Vector{T}, v̲::Vector{T}, modulo::Int) where T <: Number
	span = Vector{T}[]
	
	for λ in 0:(modulo - 1), γ in 0:(modulo - 1)
		w̲ = mod.(λ*u̲ + γ*v̲, modulo)
files.preview_highlight:
function list_span(u̲::Vector{T}, v̲::Vector{T}, modulo::Int) where T <: Number
	span = Vector{T}[]
	
	for λ in 0:(modulo - 1), γ in 0:(modulo - 1)
		w̲ = mod.(λ*u̲ + γ*v̲, modulo)

messages.text:
is objectid the same as id in Cpython ?
in Cpython ...
```[ins] In [2]: id?                                                                                         
Signature: id(obj, /)
Docstring:
Return the identity of an object.

This is guaranteed to be unique among simultaneously existing objects.
(CPython uses the object's memory address.)
Type:      builtin_function_or_method```

elements.text:

messages.text:
when I iterated a `Dict` (a sorted Dict)using `in` and `keys`function, it was disorderly. Why?
code is here:
```function test()
    table = Dict{Int64, Bool}()
    for i in 2:10
        get!(table, i, true)
    end
    for k in keys(table)
        print(k, "")
    end
end

########
output is:

julia> test()
7491023586```

messages.text:
Is there a default julia way to specify the intermediate total type of the sum/reduce function?

For example
```sum(Int64[1, 2, 3]) |> typeof  #Intermediate type is int64 and is slower to compute
sum(Int32[1, 2, 3]) |> typeof  #Intermediate type is int32 and is faster to compute

sum(Int64[1, 2, 3], intermediateType=Float64) |> typeof  #Output type is Float64 and is extremely slow to compute```
Please note, Im not talking about changing the output type of sum/reduce, but the intermediate total type (thats incremented in the forloop)

elements.text:
Is there a default julia way to specify the intermediate total type of the sum/reduce function?

For example

sum(Int64[1, 2, 3]) |> typeof  #Intermediate type is int64 and is slower to compute
sum(Int32[1, 2, 3]) |> typeof  #Intermediate type is int32 and is faster to compute

sum(Int64[1, 2, 3], intermediateType=Float64) |> typeof  #Output type is Float64 and is extremely slow to compute
Please note, Im not talking about changing the output type of sum/reduce, but the intermediate total type (thats incremented in the forloop)

messages.text: When a function is called for the first time in Julia, the function is compiled. Is it correct that this compiled version is only stored for the current Julia session.. so restarting Julia makes Julia forget all compiled functions.. or is anything saved to disk?

messages.text:
I have a dictionary of moving particles from which I want to delete any that collide, which they do whenever one particle wants to move into the coordinates occupied by another one in a volume represented by a 3D integer array.  Empty coordinates are 0, and particles check this value before ‘entering’ them by changing it to their integer key in the dictionary.

My problem is that the number of particle collisions when I run my simulation with 1000 initial particles is too high—around 700 rather than 500.  I wonder if I’m not reliably deleting particles or something.  Here’s my deleting code:

```for (p, particle in particles)
    ...
    x, y, z = new_coordinates
    if volume[x,y,z] != 0
        delete!(particles, key)
        delete!(particles, volume[x,y,z])
    else
        ...
    end
...
end```

elements.text: I have a dictionary of moving particles from which I want to delete any that collide, which they do whenever one particle wants to move into the coordinates occupied by another one in a volume represented by a 3D integer array.  Empty coordinates are 0, and particles check this value before ‘entering’ them by changing it to their integer key in the dictionary.

My problem is that the number of particle collisions when I run my simulation with 1000 initial particles is too high—around 700 rather than 500.  I wonder if I’m not reliably deleting particles or something.  Here’s my deleting code:
for (p, particle in particles)
x, y, z = new_coordinates
if volume[x,y,z] != 0
delete!(particles, key)
delete!(particles, volume[x,y,z])
else
end
end

messages.text:
I am trying to write a function that fills rows along the `i`th dimension `n` many times.  Let’s call this function `fill_n_times`.  If the function takes parameters
```fill_n_times(M, n, fill_elem; dim = 1)```
Then my expected output is
```julia> rand(Int8, 2, 2)
2×2 Array{Int8,2}:
  28  23
 -47  54

julia> fill_n_times(A, 2, 3, dim = 1) # repeat the value 3 twice along the first dimension
4×2 Array{Int64,2}:
  28  23
 -47  54
   3   3
   3   3```
The closest I have to a function like this is as follows, but it doesn’t quite do what I want (I keep getting a dimension mismatch):
```function fill_n_times(M, n, fill_elem; dim = 1)
    return cat(M, collect(Iterators.repeated(fill(fill_elem, size(M, dim)), n))..., dims = dim)
end```
How can I generalise this?  I have not very much experience working with higher dimensions.

Any```
